MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - Dublin Car Taxing Facilities.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Deputy David Andrews has sought and has been given permission to raise on the Adjournment the matter of the continuing inconvenience faced by people taxing their cars at River House. He has 20 minutes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Andrews Mr. D. Andrews
Speaker.P: I am grateful, Sir, to you for giving me the opportunity of speaking on this very important question, probably one of the most important questions raised on the Adjournment since the beginning of this Dáil, and it concerns what is perhaps the largest population base in the country. I see it under a number of headings including that of political will, the convenience of the public, the convenience of the taxpayer and the convenience of the car tax payer. In other words the individual who wishes to pay his car tax has every known obstacle in his way. River House, as we know, is situated in Chancery Street behind the Four Courts and its location alone is probably one of the most inaccessible parts of Dublin. The much harassed car owner has to go to this location if he wants to pay his car tax personally. I will not go into the question of paying one's car tax through the post. I mean no disrespect to our postmen whose integrity I have never questioned nor will I do so, but if you put your car registration book into the post then it is a question of a lottery. Will it arrive? If it arrives will it be processed and returned? How long will it take through that method or system to have your car registration book returned to you through the post? That is not what I am concerned with.

MainHeading.P: I am concerned with the convenience of the public. We public representatives who know Chancery Street and River House are embarrassed day in and day out when we see large queues of people in all sorts of weather at River House. The queue stretches around the back of the court house there almost meeting the queue again on the far side. It is as bad as that on some occasions and this should not be so. I want to make it clear that this is not an attack on the staff in River House, the officials of Dublin Corporation who operate this insidious system. Quite the contrary. I see part of my contribution being in ease and aid of these much overworked and, in my experience, very courteous staff. However, I am not so much concerned with that aspect as with going to pay one's tax willingly and being met by these obstacles.

My solution to the problem is quite simple. It has never been tried and it should be tried as a matter of urgency. We should have available to us a car tax system under which the individual car tax payer can go into a sub-post office or a post office in his or her area for the purpose of paying the car tax. That solution is simple, maybe too simple. Alternatively, if the bureaucratic and political machine cannot come to grips with that simple solution then another solution presents itself. Surely in addition to the location of the car tax registration office at River House we can have two car tax registration offices on the south side of the Liffey to cater for the people living in the southern part of the county and city of Dublin and two car tax registration offices north of the Liffey to cater for people living in the northern part, and we could have one or two car tax registration offices situated in west County Dublin. Perhaps also we could have another car tax registration office in the centre of the city. Is that too much to ask for?

I have given this matter a great deal of thought and I have concluded that the whole problem is symptomatic of the lack of political will. We run the country from Leinster House and it seems to be impossible for this moribund Government — I say that with no disrespect — to get down to this problem and solve it. We were sent here to represent the people and on this issue we are not representing them. We are responsible for the system. Civil servants and Dublin Corporation employees are operating the system that we have given them. We give the public service a system and they operate under it. The system at present operated by Dublin Corporation is nothing short of scandalous. However, the Minister is finally responsible for its application and is also responsible to the long-suffering public for the long delays and the inconvenience they have to suffer. I have received much correspondence and many representations in connection with the problem.

You go along to River House and you are lucky if you are not at the end of a 40 yard queue. You go there perhaps by bus, but inevitably if you go by car you park your car on a double yellow line and when you come out of River House you find a parking ticket on your car and, in addition, a summons for not having taxed your car. You have gone into River House to tax your car but your tax has run out and, due to the system, you are delayed for so long. It is ironic that you come out to find a parking ticket on your car and also a ticket indicating that you must go to court for not paying car tax. This is an unfortunate matter and it can be cured as a matter of urgency.

I believe I have the Minister's spiritual support in this matter but I do not know whether he can indicate his support. Being in Government he has his responsibilities. I can understand that he may not agree with me or may appear not to agree with me. He is a Dubliner and I myself am a third generation Dubliner and proud to be so. There are only a few of us left. I think the Minister will come part of the way with me on this. He is well ensconced in the philosophy of Dublin. Is it too much to give our fellow citizens the convenience of access to what is, after all, an imposition on them? They go along to pay their tax, albeit in many cases like myself unwillingly, but they do it to conform with the law of the land. Instead of having ease and access to these payment areas they meet obstruction, obstacles, inconvenience, and a wetting if the weather happens to be bad on the day they go to queue outside River House.

Another aspect is that to my knowledge people have taken a day or a half day off work to face up to this Everest-type endurance test. They may come from the other side of County Dublin, from Shankill perhaps. Consider the loss to the country in terms of service and national productivity. If our economists could quantify the loss to the economy in time because of the number of people using time going to register their cars at River House probably we would find that the loss in economic terms would be massive.

This problem comes back to politicians, ultimately, to the Government in particular. It is an extremely serious one which causes much hardship, concern and irritation. It can be solved by the introduction of a very simple system. I have asked questions and offered solutions and I hope for some action. I believe that the Minister of State has goodwill towards the suggestion for improvement.

This is not the first time I have raised this and if a solution is not forthcoming I intend to continue to raise it, to harass the Government, not in an intimidatory fashion, until a solution is found in the interests of the people of greater Dublin. I note that Deputies Skelly and Burke are anxious to contribute——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Not necessarily in that order.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Andrews Mr. D. Andrews
Speaker.P: A number of small operators are providing a service on payment of a queueing fee. People can go along and pay a queueing fee of between £3 and £5, as well as the tax charge. I must say I give full marks to those operators for the initiative but they will be put out of business if my proposed solutions are adopted. The answer to this is in the good and capable hands of the Minister of State. Let us have a system through which the thousands of greater Dublin citizens will be able to pay their tax through post offices, not necessarily sub-post offices, in the built-up areas of the city and county. Alternatively we could have a number of outlets through Dublin Corporation in the north, west and south of the city. The problem can be solved and an immense burden taken from the citizens of Dublin city and county.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I join with Deputy Andrews in appealing to the Minister of State to take action in this matter. We must remember that more than one-third of the county's population reside in the greater Dublin area and consequently that one-third of the vehicles of the country are located here. For such a massive population we have only one registration office, which means that people have to give up a day's work in order to have their cars taxed. There was never a time when productivity was more necessary and this system of taxation, which means that people lose a day's work is the very antithesis of productivity. We know the delays in the post these days and if people post their taxation forms with the required amount of money they may have to wait for their tax discs. Meanwhile, if they have to come into the city they may be approached by traffic wardens or members of the Garda and even though they may be discharged by the courts they have to go to the inconvenience of attending court and consequently lose a day's work.

MainHeading.P: I agree with Deputy Andrews that people should be allowed to transact their tax business in sub-post offices throughout the greater Dublin area. We should have at least one sub-post office in the north city and county, another in the west and a third in the south to provide a service for the public. It is ludicrous that private enterprise should be able to enter the market to provide an efficient service. For the payment of a fee motorists can hand in their tax forms and have their discs back within 24 hours. That has become necessary because the public authorities have not provided facilities for speedy collection of tax and the issuing of discs. The Minister may say this is the responsibility of Dublin Corporation, but there are Dublin County Council and Dún Laoghaire Corporation. Dublin Corporation could be responsible for the issuing of tax discs in the city and the other two bodies could provide a service for the greater Dublin area. The present registration office is beside one of the biggest Garda stations in the country, the Bridewell, and it lacks parking facilities for the thousands of people who have to call there. I ask the Minister to use his good office with the corporation to come up with a solution to this serious problem.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Skelly Mr. Skelly
Speaker.P: I support Deputies Andrews and Ray Burke in their pleas to have this archaic system reorganised. It is unfortunate that this country in many instances is seen to have to wait until a system almost breaks down or cries out for overhaul before we do anything about it. The time loss and the cost to people who have to go to the central office where there are very limited car parking facilities impose great hardship on many people who have to take a half-day or a full day away from work. It is wasteful. Queueing has been referred to. It is extraordinary in 1984 to see people having to queue to tax their cars. The position was not much different when the office was in Church Street. I do not know how the present centre was selected but the location seems to be the worst possible in Dublin for the transaction of this type of business.

When I was living in Canada 20 years ago you taxed your car on one day of the year. The tax plates were blue and white one year and white and blue the next year. On that one day the police went out on the roads and cars which did not have the proper tax plate were just swished off the road and their owners had to tax their cars before they were allowed back on the roads again. It was all done in two or three days and all cars were taxed for the rest of the year.

We have a different system. We can tax cars for a quarter, six months or nine months, or for the entire year. It is so bad and has been occuring for so long that some people are selling their cars and advertising them as “taxed for the rest of the year” as an incentive to purchasers. We have the ridiculous small disc which you would need a pair of binoculars to see, unless the car is almost stopped, to decide whether the car has been taxed. We lose much revenue by messing around like this. It is a very inefficient method of collecting tax. It could very easily be changed if we had the will to do so.

MainHeading.P: The postal service is ridiculous because if you send away your tax form you may not get the disc back in time and in the meantime you may be summonsed for not having the car taxed and for not displaying the disc. You have the bother of going to court even though you may have told the garda that you have sent the tax form away. He cannot accept that from everybody. If this were a private business problem it would have been sorted out years ago. Here we have an enormous amount of business coming in, people are queueing to pay their tax all the time. An enormous number of people are willing to purchase the tax system. All we have to do is sit down and work out an up-to-date method of motor tax collection. In Dublin we seem to have an into-town mentality: people go into town to do things that they should not have to do, whether it is to pay the ESB bill, the telephone bill or the tax bill. It is ridiculous. The Minister has the goodwill of everybody on all sides of the House to work out an up-to-date system.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The whole point of having an Adjournment debate is to get a reply from a Minister. The Minister of State must be allowed his time to reply.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Skelly Mr. Skelly
Speaker.P: I will conclude by asking the Minister to do something about the problem.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. F. O'Brien) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. F. O'Brien)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. F. O'Brien)
Speaker.P: I acknowledge that there are grounds for concern in the quality of the service provided to the general public in the matter of taxing their cars. However, I assure the House that I intend taking action in this regard. It is a matter that Deputy Andrews has raised before. I have raised it also, as have most Dublin Deputies.

MainHeading.P: Of a national total of 897,000 vehicles registered, 235,000, or 26 per cent, are registered in Dublin. All these vehicles are registered in a single office which is located in River House and quite adjacent to the Fourt Courts. Arising from discussions between officers of my Department and Dublin Corporation, as well as from a subsequent examination undertaken by the Department, I am prepared to agree in principle to the opening of a sub-office, on a trial basis, on the south side of Dublin. By a trial basis I do not mean the provision of an office as a temporary expediency but we will see how it operates and decide whether we should do something else in conjunction with the staff.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Andrews Mr. D. Andrews
Speaker.P: Where will this office be located?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. O'Brien Mr. F. O'Brien
Speaker.P: It will be somewhere between Dún Laoghaire and Tallaght and at some central point to which people will have easy access but we do not have the location yet. We are hoping, though, that it will be available within a short time. I refute the suggestion that we are a moribund Government.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Andrews Mr. D. Andrews
Speaker.P: What the Minister is talking about is only a partial solution to the problem.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. O'Brien Mr. F. O'Brien
Speaker.P: I have indicated that. We have increased the staff.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Skelly Mr. Skelly
Speaker.P: What the Minister is proposing is only a partial solution. His answer is pathetic and ridiculous. I cannot believe it. It is childish.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Minister must be allowed time to reply.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. O'Brien Mr. F. O'Brien
Speaker.P: The question of appointing additional staff is being considered in the context of the review of Dublin motor taxation which was carried out by the Department. Perhaps if Deputy Skelly would listen he would not regard my answer as childish. I may have some further information for him.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Skelly Mr. Skelly
Speaker.P: The Minister has made a bad start.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. O'Brien Mr. F. O'Brien
Speaker.P: The primary cause of the complaints is that apparently people prefer to queue and register their cars personally, although there is a postal system in operation. That system has been criticised but the waiting period has been reduced to two weeks. The problem is often worse at opening time and immediately after the lunch break but we are considering ways in which an improvement might be made. I consider a two-week wait to be reasonable in respect of the use of the postal system, so perhaps more people should avail of that procedure.

The possibility of the use of the Post Office in this area has been mentioned. It is a possibility that I have referred to also in the past. We will have discussions with An Post with a view to operating with them some system on a trial basis. The possibility of any such system was ruled out on the basis of legal, administrative, financial and accounting problems. It was ruled out by some of those people who have spoken tonight but who were in power then. However, I am not ruling it out.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Andrews Mr. D. Andrews
Speaker.P: Sometimes power isolates one from reality.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. O'Brien Mr. F. O'Brien
Speaker.P: It is amazing what isolates one from reality. I know the reality and that is why I am prepared to do something about the problem we are discussing. The possibility of providing the service through the Post Office will be pursued. If, after examination, the possibility is considered feasible we will go ahead with it.

Later this year we will be introducing a Bill providing for the filing of certain vehicle data at the Shannon computerised space centre. That will take the workload off the staff thereby permitting more of them to give their time to expediting applications for vehicle registration.

MainHeading.P: The question raised is one that has been troubling the motorists in Dublin county and city for some time. I am confident that the setting up of an office on the south side and on a main thoroughfare will prove successful. We are not living in a world in which such matters can be dealt with overnight. We would hope to have the co-operation of staffs concerned in respect of any change that may be proposed, whether in conjunction with An Post or within the Department. If we have that co-operation we will make progress. The problem has been left aside for far too long. When Fianna Fáil were in Government they ignored it but something is being done now.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Andrews Mr. D. Andrews
Speaker.P: This debate is not about politics.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. O'Brien Mr. F. O'Brien
Speaker.P: I am making the point——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Skelly Mr. Skelly
Speaker.P: There is little use in making a point.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. O'Brien Mr. F. O'Brien
Speaker.P: I have not cast aspersions on any Government. Someone else did, thereby making this matter political. I am prepared to pursue this problem until I am satisfied that the motorists of Dublin city and county are getting a fair deal in terms of facilities for registering their cars and I will proceed on those lines with a good degree of haste.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: Security services are liable to VAT at the rate of 23 per cent and taxable persons acquiring these services for business purposes are normally entitled to a credit for the tax borne in the cost of the services.

I am advised by the Revenue Commissioners that, in the case in question and in the case of most shopping centres and similar property developments, security and other costs, such as the cleaning and lighting of public areas and insurance, are borne in the first instance by the landlord and reimbursed to him by the tenants under a covenant in the lease. However, once the initial lettings of developed property have been completed most landlords are no longer taxable persons under the VAT system. They do not continue to be registered for the tax and cannot, therefore, claim a credit for the tax borne on the services in question. Neither can the tenants of the property claim a credit because although the cost might rightly be regarded as having in effect been ultimately borne jointly by them as an addition to their rents, the various services are not supplied to them.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason for discrimination in payment of social welfare rates for married and unmarried females.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: Differences in the rates of social welfare payments for married women and other categories have been a feature of social insurance since the present unified system was introduced in 1952.

This approach was undoubtedly relevant at that time when it was exceptional for a married woman to take up employment outside the home. Married women would normally have looked to their husbands for maintenance and those who did engage in employment would have done so, generally speaking, in order to augment the family income. The same level of responsibility or need would not have existed for them as in the case of other beneficiaries and it would also have been necessary to ensure that the level of payments to them did not provide an incentive to exploit the system. The married women who were not dependent on their husbands — such as those who were separated and not being maintained by their husbands — received the full rates of payment.

MainHeading.P: The elimination of the differences referred to is being considered in the context of the provision of equal treatment for men and women in matters of social security in accordance with EEC Directive 79/7/EEC. Legislative proposals to deal with this matter will be introduced later this year.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the reason the gardí removed a video machine from the home of a person (details supplied) in Dublin 12; if they were entitled to do this on the basis of their warrant; if they were entitled to strip search the person in her own home which they did; if he is aware that some furniture was damaged during the search of the house; if he will arrange for this matter to be investigated to ensure that the law has not been exceeded; and when the video will be returned.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I am informed by the Garda authorities that the search of the house in question was carried out on foot of a properly authorised search warrant which also gave a right of search of persons. I am informed that two banghardaí were involved in the search of the women referred to but that they did not have occasion to have any physical contact with her. I am further informed that no damage was caused to any property during the search.
The video machine was removed for the purpose of further Garda inquiries which will be conducted as speedily as possible.
The Garda authorities are satisfied that the members concerned acted properly and within the law on the occasion.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L. Fitzgerald Mr. L. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if in view of an order made by him recently directing all prison staff at Portlaoise and Limerick to shave off beards or transfer to other institutions he will state when and where breaches of security at prisons have occurred in recent years that have been associated with the wearing of beards by prison staff; and the reason this order together with one directing the same officers to resume wearing officer caps after three years should be necessary at this time.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): Traditionally officers of the Prison Service, as members of one of the disciplined services of the State, have been clean-shaven and have worn uniform caps on duty. Regrettably the standards of discipline, neatness and deportment had become eroded in recent years and, among other things, caps ceased to be worn by many officers and some officers grew beards. The authorities of the security services were particularly concerned by the fact that the wearing of beards by officers in Portlaoise and Limerick prisons might lead to problems of identification in certain circumstances since a proportion of prisoners in those prisons also wear beards.

The situation has been of concern to my predecessors and to me. At my first meeting with the Prison Officers Association in January 1983 I specifically asked the officers of the association to co-operate in getting their members to wear caps and appear clean-shaven on duty but to no avail. In the circumstances I was satisfied that it was in the best interests of the Prison Service that the directions in question should issue.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
